Available in French REASONS FOR DECISION

OVERVIEW

[1] The Appellant, Veroni[REDACTED], is a citizen of Trinidad and Tobago. She

became a permanent resident of Canada in 2012. After landing in Canada, the A ppellant stayed

here for about two months. She returned to Trinidad and Tobago to wrap up her affairs. Later, her

parents became ill, which prevented her from retuning back to Canada sooner.

[2] In 2020, the Appellant applied for a Permanent Resident Travel D ocument to return to

Canada, but the visa officer refused her application. The Appellant did not respect her residency

obligations to be present in Canada in the relevant five -year period for at least 730 days.1 In the

relevant five -year period, she was pr esent for only 136 days.

[3] The Appellant appealed the visa officer’s decision to the Immigration Appeal Division. She

admitted that the visa officer ’s decision is l...

Reasons for Decision



[1] On May 8, 2008 Member [REDACTED] of the Immigration Appeal Division (IAD) granted Or[REDACTED] (the appellant) a stay (on conditions) of the deportation order issued against him on May 7, 2007. The stay was gr anted to the appellant based on the written recommendation of the respondent. The duration of the stay was for one year and it included 12 conditions. [2] On February 25, 2010 Member [REDACTED] of the IAD extended the stay for another six months because the appellant did not obtain his passport. Minister’s counsel at that time consented to the extension of the stay in order to allow the appellant to obtain his passport. [3] On November 2, 2010 the stay was further extended. On December 9, 2010 the appellant was sent a Notice of Reconsideration and on March 7, 2011 the Minister submitted a written statement indicating that the appellant had not complied with his stay and pointed to further criminality, his failure to obtain a passport and his failure to provide a Statement of Compliance. [4] At today’s hear...

Oral Reasons for Decision

[1] This is the decision in the appeal by [REDACTED] (the appellant) from a deportation order made against him on November 16, 2000 following his conviction for trafficking narcotics on April 26, 1996 where he received a sentence of 3 years’ imprisonment. [2] This deportation order was stayed by the Immigrat ion Appeal Division’s Member [REDACTED] on December 10, 2001. At that time, following a recommendation by the Minister’s counsel and taking into account different humanitarian and compassionate factors, Member [REDACTED] concluded that such a stay was warranted. REASONS FOR DECISION

Introduction [1] These are the reasons for the decision in the appeal, pursuant to subsection 63(3) of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act

(IRPA ) of T[REDACTED] (the principal appellant), his wife, [REDACTED] (the appellant) and E[REDACTED] (the minor appellant). They are appealing the de termination by the Minister’s Delegate, made on September 27, 2006, to issue a departure orders against them as a persons described in subsection 41(b) of IRPA

, because the Minister’s Delegate was satisfied, on a balance of probabilities, there were grounds to believe that the appellants were permanent residents who were inadmissible to Canada for failing to comp ly with the residency obligation contained in section 28 of IRPA

. [2] Specifically, the appellants had failed to reside in Canada for at least 730 days in the five- year period immediately after they became permanent residents, which was on March 27, 2003. The Minister’s Delegate was also not sati sfied, pursuant to section 28(2)(c) of IRPA

, that there were sufficient ...

RAD File No. / N° de dossier de la S AR :



Reasons and Decision

[1] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] (the Appellant), a citizen of China, appe als a decision of the Refugee

Protection Division (RPD) denying her claim for refugee protection. She has not submitte d new

evidence in support of her appeal. The Appellant asks that the Refugee Appeal Division (RAD)

set aside the decision of the RPD and s ubstitute a decision with its own determination that the

Appellant is a Convention refugee or a person in need of protection. In the alternative, the

Appellant requests that the RAD refer the matter back to the RPD with a differently -constituted

panel.

DE TERMINATION

attempt to find a solution to a debilitating ankle injury...

REASONS FOR DECISION

who claim to be citizens of Somalia, appeal a decision of the Refugee Protection Division (RPD)

claims and they have requested an oral hearing. The Appellants further request that the Refugee

Appeal Division (RAD) find that they are Convention refugees. Alternatively the Appellants

request that the matter be remitted to the RPD for reconsideration by a differently -constituted

panel.

RAD sets aside the determination of the RPD and substitutes its decision that t he Appellants are

Convention re fugees. The appeals are allowed.

clan who used to live in [REDACTED] , Somalia....

allegedly killed Mr. [REDACTED] sister either in 2010 or 2011. Mr. [REDACTED] left Haiti for Brazil in June

the mistreatme nt of Haitians in Brazil. Mr. [REDACTED] traveled to the United States and ended up

crossing the border into Canada in [REDACTED] 2017. By the time of the RPD hearing in this case,

more than two years had passed since Mr. [REDACTED] departure from Brazil.

REASONS FOR DECISION

OVERVIEW

[1] The appellant , [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] , a citizen of Congo -Brazzaville , is

appealing against a decision of the Refugee Protection Division (RPD) rejecting his refugee

protection claim . He argue d that his life was in danger because he was being sought by the

Congolese police for his involvement in the electio n campaign of a defeated candidate during the

2016 presidential election . The RPD found that the appellant was not credible and that he was

not involved in the presidential campaign. The appellant is contesting that finding on the grounds

that the RPD gave too much weight to peripheral aspects of the record when assessing his

credibility. Furthermore, he argues that there was a breach of procedural fairness during the

hearing because the panel repeatedly interrupted his lawyer when she was trying to speak .

panel’s interventions were justified. However, I conclude tha...

Disponible en français REASONS FOR DECISION

INTRODUCTION

[1] The appellant, Moha[REDACTED], appeals the decision of a v isa officer that he

failed to comply with the residency obligation for permanent residen ts, as set out in section 28 of

the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA). The Officer determined that the appellant

had not been in Canada for 730 days in the 5 -year period under consideration, that being March

15, 2012 to March 15, 2017.

[2] The appellant brings his appeal pursuant to section 63(4) of the IRPA . He does not

challenge the legal validity of the Officer’s decision but submits that humanitarian and

compass ionate considerations warrant special relief.

REASONS FOR DECISION

[1] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] [REDACTED] (the “Appellant”) is alleging to be a citizen of Somalia and is

appealing a decision of the Refugee Protection Division (RPD) denying his claim for refugee

protection. The Appellant is requesting that the Refugee Appeal Division (RAD) set aside the

RPD’s negative determination and find that he is a Convention refugee or a person in need of

protection. In the alternative, the Appellant requests the RAD refer the matter back to the RPD

for redetermination by a differently constituted panel. The Appellant has requested to submit

new evidence and has requested an oral hearing.

DETERMINATION OF THE APPEAL

[2] The RAD dismisses the appeal and confirms the decision of the RPD that the Appellant is

neither a Convention refugee nor a person in need of protection, pursuant to paragraph 111(1)( a)

of the Immigration and Refugee Protection Act (IRPA).1

Background

Darod clan. He alleges he was frequently...
